newsitem.title: CHINA: China predicts more storm damage this year.
newsitem.headline: China predicts more storm damage this year.

text.p: China is bracing for more destructive coastal storms this year and expects heavy economic losses, the Xinhua news agency said on Friday.

"China will have natural ocean disasters with greater frequency and severity this year, with a large area of the East China Sea as the centre," Xinhua said, quoting the National Bureau of Oceanography.

Up to four typhoon-linked storms were expected to lash the southern island province of Hainan and the coastal provinces of Guangxi, Guangdong, Fujian, Zhejiang and Jiangsu between July and October, Ye Renmiao, director of the bureau's ocean monitoring department, said.
Damage from destructive waves measuring over four metres (13 ft) high, would exceed last year's levels, Xinhua said.
Huge waves were likely to affect parts of the Yellow Sea and the East China Sea, Ye said.

Annual economic losses from such natural disasters surged to 20 billion yuan ($2.4 billion) in 1996 from just one billion yuan ($120 million) in the early 1980s due in part to the rapid economic development of China' coastal areas, Xinhua said. It gave no further details.
